verse: That is how David escaped, and from there, he went to the cave of Adullam to hide. When his brothers and the rest of his family heard he was there, they went down to be with him.
A group gathered around him, composed of those who were in debt or who were not content with Saul or who were in trouble. Soon David was captain of about 400 such men.
David traveled then to Mizpah in Moab, the homeland of his great-grandmother, Ruth, to address the king of Moab.
So David left his parents there, and they remained with the king of Moab as long as David remained in the stronghold.
David was visited later by Gad the prophet.

Meanwhile Saul was sitting, spear in hand, under a gnarled and bushy tamarisk tree on the crest of a high hill in Gibeah. His servants were standing around him when he heard the news that David and his followers had been located.
Doeg the Edomite stood among Saul’s servants.
So the king sent for the priest Ahimelech, son of Ahitub, and for all his family who were the priests at Nob, and they came before Saul.

Then he went after Nob, the city of the priests, with his sword and utterly destroyed everything he found there—all the men, women, children, and infants. Doeg even turned his blade against the oxen, donkeys, and sheep.
Only Abiathar, son of Ahimelech, son of Ahitub, escaped, and he fled to David for protection.
He informed David that Saul had massacred the priests of the Eternal.
